Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Harnessing human intelligence for mapping on custom reconfigurable architectures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Custom domain-specific architectures have great promise for achieving energy-efficient flexible designs for a suite of applications. For practical deployment, however, there is a great need to develop smart algorithms for mapping applications of interest onto these architectures. The main thrust of this research is to discover novel mapping algorithms by making use of human intuition and ability to recognize patterns and opportunities even in complex problems. Participants are presented with successively more difficult mapping problems in a game environment, and the vast dataset of participants' moves is analyzed to recognize common patterns used by successful game participants. The insights gained from strategic moves humans make while solving problems based on their visual intuition and experience can be used to discover new mapping approaches that are beyond what can be conceived with traditional algorithms. For broad scope and impact, this research places particular attention on multiple architectural designs, highly constrained (and thus very difficult) mapping problems, and engaging a broad community of contributors through crowdsourcing.

Fast and effective mapping techniques, and a methodology for developing new such techniques as needed has the potential to inspire architectural innovation and result in production of devices that are faster, cheaper, and smarter. Results from this research can advance next generation portable/wearable devices critical to health, safety and security, personal multimedia, and aerospace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research is to discover fast and effective mapping algorithms for custom reconfigurable devices by harnessing human intelligence. We believe that the next generation of mapping algorithms will require a level of creativity, pattern recognition, and learning from experience that are characteristics of human strategies when faced with complex mapping problems, and our goal is to discover such strategies and use them to design novel and effective mapping algorithms.

In order to uncover human mapping strategies, we encapsulate the mapping problem in a game environment and invite contributions from players world-wide through crowdsourcing. We have demonstrated the power of human computation for mapping to coarse-grained reconfigurable architectures and leverage insights from human gameplay to develop new algorithms that outperform long term standards. We have developed a highly interactive online mapping game, UNTANGLED, a recipient of the People's Choice Award in the 2012 international science and engineering visualization challenge conducted by the National Science Foundation and Science. Our game has been online since May 2012 and has attracted more than 900 players who have contributed to more than 12000 mapping solutions. We have also designed an architecture game to create, build, and explore low energy architectural solutions for custom domain-specific architectures. We have given demonstration of our interactive design environments at the SIGDA University Demo, Design Automation Conference. We have conducted several outreach events using our gaming environments including online world-wide gaming competitions, freshmen game night at one of the UNT's dorms, research seminars to Texas Academy of Science and Mathematics (TAMS) students and UNT honors college students, game events for Society of Women Engineers (SWE) at UNT, Design and Untangle game event for the College of Engineering Summer Program for Undergraduate Research (SUPER) students, events for high school and middle school students. Our games are broadly accessible and players do not need any special engineering background to play these games. Our games can be used to promote computational thinking among people without science or engineering background.
